bestBHT.bht: The mention of Peter in this account is not meant to highlight his denial of Jesus, but rather to bring comfort to him in his deep sorrow and assure him of Christ's love and forgiveness. This personalized message from the Risen Christ was a significant event that transformed the doubts of the apostles into unwavering certainty. The promised meeting in Galilee not only fulfilled Jesus' previous words, but also demonstrated His incredible goodness and graciousness towards Peter, despite his shortcomings.

Henry Alford: The mention of him here is probably merely official—as the ‘first among equals.’"
We cannot say that others of the Apostles may not have denied their Master besides Peter.
It must not be concluded from this that we have a trace of Peter’s hand in the narrative.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: This Second Gospel, being drawn up—as all the earliest tradition states—under the eye of Peter, or from materials chiefly furnished by him...
...there is something deeply affecting in the preservation of this little clause by Mark alone.
...that he goeth before you into Galilee; there shall ye see him, as he said unto you.
Philip Schaff: But. Emphatic: instead of lingering here, go tell, etc."
And Peter. A special token of love to this one who had denied Him, and a recognition of his prominence among his equals.
As he said to you. Chap. Mark 14:28; see on Matthew 28:7.
Archibald T. Robertson: Peter remembered gratefully this special message from the Risen Christ.
An event that changed doubt to certainty with the apostles.
John Gill: Peter is particularly mentioned, not as distinct from the apostles, or as if he was not one of them, having sinned in the manner he had done; much less because he was the chief of them; but to comfort him in his great sorrow, on account of his fall; and to encourage him to meet Christ with the rest of his disciples...

This is a kind intimation, in favour of Peter; none of the other evangelists observe it; but this Gospel being published, as is thought by some, under the direction and examination of Peter himself, he was careful to relate every thing, that either aggravated his own crime, or illustrated the grace of God, and love of Christ towards him.
The Persic version puts Peter first, rendering it, 'say to Cephas and the rest of the disciples'; all copies, and other versions, put him last...
John Wesley: And Peter — Though he so oft denied his Lord. What amazing goodness was this!

bhtAttempts.bht: The mention of Peter's name in this verse is not to emphasize his denial of Jesus, but rather to comfort him in his great sorrow and remind him of the love and forgiveness of Christ. It is a special token of love and recognition of his prominence among the other apostles. This message from the Risen Christ, specifically for Peter, was an event that changed doubt to certainty for the apostles. The promised meeting in Galilee not only fulfilled Jesus' previous words, but also served as a reminder of His amazing goodness and grace towards Peter, despite his denial.

The mention of Peter's name in this passage is not a condemnation of his denial of Jesus, but rather a comforting gesture to remind him of Christ's love and forgiveness. This special message from the Risen Christ, specifically for Peter, is a powerful reminder of the transformation that occurred within the apostles as their doubt turned into certainty. The promised meeting in Galilee fulfills Jesus' previous words, while showcasing His amazing goodness and grace towards Peter, despite his denial.

The mention of Peter in this account is not meant to highlight his denial of Jesus, but rather to bring comfort to him in his deep sorrow and assure him of Christ's love and forgiveness. This personalized message from the Risen Christ was a significant event that transformed the doubts of the apostles into unwavering certainty. The promised meeting in Galilee not only fulfilled Jesus' previous words, but also demonstrated His incredible goodness and graciousness towards Peter, despite his shortcomings.

The mention of Peter in this narrative is not intended to highlight his denial of Jesus, but rather to provide comfort and reassurance to him in his deep sorrow. This unique message from the Risen Christ served as a powerful reminder of His love and forgiveness. The promised meeting in Galilee fulfilled Jesus' previous words and solidified the apostles' unwavering certainty. It is a poignant detail preserved by Mark alone, reflecting Peter's grateful remembrance of this special message.

The mention of Peter in this narrative is not to single him out for his denial of Jesus, but rather to provide him with comfort and assurance in his sorrow. This special message from the Risen Christ, tailored specifically for Peter, reflects the transformation that took place among the apostles, as their doubts were replaced with unwavering certainty. The promised meeting in Galilee not only fulfills Jesus' previous words, but also showcases His remarkable grace and love towards Peter, despite his shortcomings. It is a touching detail preserved by Mark alone, illustrating Peter's grateful remembrance of this significant message.
